text: Anyone know where can get finishing time for individual horses in UK and Ireland races? Ideally going back as far as possible. I know there is some sectional data out there which goes to like 2015 and covers about 50% of races but was looking for more data than this.

elements.text: Anyone know where can get finishing time for individual horses in UK and Ireland races? Ideally going back as far as possible. I know there is some sectional data out there which goes to like 2015 and covers about 50% of races but was looking for more data than this.

text: Racing post has this and is easily scraped.

elements.text: Racing post has this and is easily scraped.

text: Take care with how you use it though - you can't just assume that every horse runs as fast as it can, they tend to stop bothering if they're not in with a chance of a place. They also do the minimum necessary to win.

text: The only readily available time that is comprehensive will be the race winners time. If you are desperate to have times for every runner you could approximate it by converting the lengths behind the winner into time behind the winner and subtract it from the race winning time

elements.text: The only readily available time that is comprehensive will be the race winners time. If you are desperate to have times for every runner you could approximate it by converting the lengths behind the winner into time behind the winner and subtract it from the race winning time

text: I've studied this in the past and the best I've found is to use the finishing time of the winner and then approximate any others that were pretty close (i.e. <2 lengths away). The rest of the field are eased off once beaten, so the time is irrelevant. Plus horses spend most of their racing careers NOT running at their best.

elements.text: I've studied this in the past and the best I've found is to use the finishing time of the winner and then approximate any others that were pretty close (i.e. <2 lengths away). The rest of the field are eased off once beaten, so the time is irrelevant. Plus horses spend most of their racing careers NOT running at their best.

text: <@U01LV8RS58A> has joined the channel
Yeah, I tend to avoid time altogether and go off of lengths beaten which I put through a transformation so that the value diminishes as the distance from the winner decreases

elements.text: Yeah, I tend to avoid time altogether and go off of lengths beaten which I put through a transformation so that the value diminishes as the distance from the winner decreases

text: <@UK55EGNLA> Perhaps you could just do whatever analysis you planned with what's readily available and see if you get anything from it - that's quite a lot of racing so you should see at least some efficacy if your approach is worthwhile. You wouldn't want to spend ages gathering data for an idea that flunks - 80/20 rule and all that.

elements.text: Perhaps you could just do whatever analysis you planned with what's readily available and see if you get anything from it - that's quite a lot of racing so you should see at least some efficacy if your approach is worthwhile. You wouldn't want to spend ages gathering data for an idea that flunks - 80/20 rule and all that.

text: <@U01LX0E7G9H> has joined the channel

<@UBS7QANF3>, <@U016535QCJ2> how do you guys go about dealing with injuries/injury time-outs for in-play tennis?
1. is there some "injury feed" out there?
2. do you pay someone to watch games or for example have a "strange market price" detection of some form to prevent/minimise losses when people start betting the injuries?
3. do you ever resume betting on match where someone had an injury timeout or depends?
many thanks in advance! very curious about your experience with this.

elements.text: how do you guys go about dealing with injuries/injury time-outs for in-play tennis?
is there some "injury feed" out there?
do you pay someone to watch games or for example have a "strange market price" detection of some form to prevent/minimise losses when people start betting the injuries?
do you ever resume betting on match where someone had an injury timeout or depends?
many thanks in advance! very curious about your experience with this.

text: I know <@UBS7QANF3> deals with them, but at the moment I just "cop" any losses

elements.text: I know
deals with them, but at the moment I just "cop" any losses

text: My modelling suggests (and actual betting suggests) that they just aren't a big proportion of losses (and sometimes we win from then as well)

elements.text: My modelling suggests (and actual betting suggests) that they just aren't a big proportion of losses (and sometimes we win from then as well)

text: The main reason is that if you are betting each point (or potentially betting each point) you have usually "done" most of your money by then

elements.text: The main reason is that if you are betting each point (or potentially betting each point) you have usually "done" most of your money by then

text: So to answer the questions directly:

elements.text: So to answer the questions directly:

text: 1. The Betfair API does have information about injuries (but no WTA at the moment, and I don't think it covers the Australian season)

elements.text: The Betfair API does have information about injuries (but no WTA at the moment, and I don't think it covers the Australian season)

text: 2. Will never do anything other than full automation so will never integrate any sort of vision. In terms of strange price detection I have spent a lot of time looking but mainly you end up with false positives that tend to be very profitable

elements.text: 2. Will never do anything other than full automation so will never integrate any sort of vision. In terms of strange price detection I have spent a lot of time looking but mainly you end up with false positives that tend to be very profitable

text: 3. I just keep going, so have certainly thrown money away on some matches through more bets (lots more bets)

elements.text: 3. I just keep going, so have certainly thrown money away on some matches through more bets (lots more bets)

text: Last thing from my point of view: it seems my model is most profitable when the market prices are WAY out from what would be expected. For big price swings the market gets it wrong more often than right (and that surprised me). But to be profitable you need to hold your nerve, because it makes for some truly awful losses

elements.text: Last thing from my point of view: it seems my model is most profitable when the market prices are WAY out from what would be expected. For big price swings the market gets it wrong more often than right (and that surprised me). But to be profitable you need to hold your nerve, because it makes for some truly awful losses

3. 100%

text: Detecting strange market prices also has value for detecting match fixes but you do need to be careful as <@U016535QCJ2> says because to find value you need to disagree with the market

text: Every now and again I will have a big win, review the scores and prices, and will come to the conclusion that I have no idea why the market had bizarre prices. Occasionally I am on the receiving end of those as well
